timeline.bodyText: Could restore the failure state message here, perhaps.
timeline.author: Ceiu
Ceiu

timeline.bodyText:
Since you're changing these 2 places to stop trying to persist the failed queuing of a job, there is one more place that does that which should probably change: the catch block in postJobStatusMessage().
This is called in 2 places:

When queuing a job as normally
When the execution of a job failed with retry=true and we're trying to re-queue it.

It should probably stop trying to persist the FAILED state, and just re-throw (it already rethrows) the exception.
timeline.author: nikosmoum

replies.bodyText: In both of those cases, we have a job that has already been persisted, and the failure is more likely from being unable to send an artemis message. If it is a DB error, the exception on update will be rethrown (as you noted) and that will propagate through the system and fail in the expected way.
replies.author: Ceiu

replies.bodyText: That's fine, but we still have another problem because in the first case, the state that was persisted was CREATED, and we can't move it from CREATED to FAILED (invalid transition). And if we did change that to ABORTED, then the 2nd case wouldn't work because FAILED_WITH_RETRY -> ABORTED is invalid. So maybe we should add ABORTED to the valid transitions from FAILED_WITH_RETRY? (alternatively, we could simply make CREATED -> FAILED valid, but I would prefer the other solution).
replies.author: nikosmoum

replies.bodyText: Ahh, gotcha. I've added the FAILED_WITH_RETRY -> ABORTED transition, and updated the exception handler in message posting to use ABORTED.
replies.author: Ceiu

timeline.bodyText: Looks like this was copied from a top-level class to an internal class here. We should probably delete ImportConflictJobException.java then (no need to keep both)
timeline.author: nikosmoum

timeline.bodyText: Are we not able to lazy-load this field after all? (or is that not desirable any more because the constraint memory issue is handled anyway?)
timeline.author: nikosmoum

replies.bodyText: Haven't gone back to check. The first method ended up causing tons of problems and not working, so I just dropped it to a standard field for the interim. I think it'll be fine since we will ever have around 10 populated instances per node at any given time outside of the remaining problem area that needs to be addressed in the bulk-fetching of jobs.

timeline.bodyText: Since this method isn't used anywhere else, should we just delete it? I can't imagine where else we'd need it

timeline.message:
1843186: Refactor job constraints to reduce memory footprint

- Refactored the job constraints system such that each constraint
  performs its own lookup of potentially conflicting jobs, rather
  than fetching all non-terminal jobs
- JobManager now throws exceptions instead of unmanaged AsyncJobStatus
  instances when a job cannot be queued due to an internal failure
- The way job data has been stored has changed substantially;
  arguments, metadata, and the job result are no longer stored in
  a single serialized blob. Job arguments are now stored in a separate
  table, metadata has been dropped and the job result is its own
  column on the base table.
- Added a new column and field to AsyncJobStatus for storing the
  correlation ID of the task that triggered the job
- The JobExecutionContext is now responsible for setting the result
  of a job, rather than returning an object from the job's execute
  method
- JobExecutionContext is no longer an interface that is applied
  to the backing model objects
- Jobs no longer return values to set a result, instead setting the
  result by calling JobExecutionContext.setJobResult
- Removed the now-redundant ImportConflictJobException
- Output for the result field of the AsyncJobStatusDTO is now flagged
  as a raw JSON field
- Messaging exceptions will now set the job state to ABORTED instead
  of FAILED
- Added a transition from FAILED_WITH_RETRY to ABORTED to allow
  proper handling of the case where a failed job is intended to be
  re-queued but the message cannot be sent for any reason

timeline.bodyText: Now that we use an objectmapper excplicitly here, to serialize result objects, we should remove the old infrastructure we used to do that with the @Convert annotation: JobDataJsonConverter / AbstractJsonConverter.java
timeline.author: nikosmoum

replies.bodyText:
AbstractJsonConverter is the JSON compliment to ResultDataUserType. We no longer have an immediate use for it now, but that's what we should use in the future.
One thing that comes to mind here is perhaps using a one-way version of the converter rather than explicitly converting it ourselves. Might be cleaner than what is currently in this PR.
replies.author: Ceiu

replies.bodyText: You can do it that way if you want, or leave it as a todo?
replies.author: nikosmoum
